content.question:
<math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous, plus O H with a negative one charge, aqueous, reacts to produce, C 2 H 3 O 2, with a negative one charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

A student carried out a titration using <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The net ionic equation for the neutralization reaction that occurs during the titration is represented above. The <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added from a buret to the <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a flask. The equivalence point was reached when a total of <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> had been added to the flask. How does the amount of <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the flask after the addition of <math alttext="5.0 millilters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> compare to the amount of <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the flask after the addition of <math alttext="1.0 millileter" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>1.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>mL</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and what is the reason for this result?

choices.label: It is less because more <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> reacted with the base.
It is the same because the equivalence point has not been reached.
It is the same because all of the coefficients in the neutralization equation are 1.

It is greater because <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a proton donor.

content.answer: It is less because more <math alttext="H C 2 H 3 O 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> reacted with the base.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
